issue.title: Think about tuning the script cache/sigcache ratios
issue.body: After #10192, we have two separate caches, which are in memory blocks of equal size. This is likely not the best possible tuning, but sadly its tricky to get right because the sigcache is now used more as a DoS protection/reorg speedup and less as a cache used in normal operation. See-also, @JeremyRubin's suggestion of using the same table and further discussion at, eg, https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/10192#issuecomment-313334895.

events.body:
I am astonished that as many random memory access as we're making for these things is actually well tuned.   I'd really like to understand how 8 way fanout is optimal, if it is, since that amount of memory latency should significantly slower than e.g. four way fanout into buckets of two esp with caches much larger than L3. Reports were that it wasn't which suggests to me that something is wrong, either in our implementation or in my understanding of the hardware, maybe our hash function is too slow and thats obscuring it.

Another thing to look at is tuning the eviction/epoch counter part.

Greg I think your understanding is deficient, the actual expected number of probes should be a lot closer to 1 for signatures that exist. This is because a recently inserted transaction should be close to it's first hash-index and a recently inserted transaction is more likely to be mined.

If you want to simulate the worst case you should write a benchmark that tests the cache with a block that has all previously unseen signatures/transactions.

I have started to look into this a little further to see whether it might be worth putting more work into, but so far I am not convinced.

I first added some logging to the cache lookups to get a better idea of how well the caches are performing currently, which yeilded these results when logging every minute, plus isolated block acceptance stats:

The sig cache is hitting at almost exactly ~50% which is the expected best-rate performance: when we first see a signature we miss, then cache it, then hit on the next usage (only happens once more during ATMP).

The script cache hit-rate is ~zero outside of block acceptance (first time we miss, then store), but inside block connection, and so long as the node has been running a while (i.e. has a "warm" mempool which also has relay policies ~ matching those of miners) I observe an almost 100% script cache hit-rate.

Both cases here are the intended behaviour of the caches, as I understand them.

Does using a different fanout pattern, or size configuration bring us any benefit? To find out more I added a simple benchmark to test lookup performance of an 8 and 2-way fanout (I also tried a 4-way fanout into buckets of 2, but I think my implementation was not optimal, and in any case we can consider results from the 2-way fanout I think). This is the closest scenario to the block connection case where we consult the cache(s) but don't store anything in them (i.e. cause evictions), and this is the case IMO that we should care most about.

These results were as follows:

- 8-way fanout: 193.5s per 4,000 lookups (48.4ns per lookup)
- 2-way fanout: 142.3s per 4,000 lookups (35.6ns per lookup)

So 2-way fanout (as expected) is 26% faster for pure lookups. There is certainly a little room for improvement by changing fanout of the cache, but would it be worth it?

If we consider that a block might have ~4k lookups in the script cache, then it follows that the time spent doing lookups in the cache would be:

- 4,000 lookups  48.4ns = 194s total cache time (8-way)
- 4,000 lookups  35.6ns = 142s total cache time (2-way)

This could mean a saving of ~52s per block by switching to a naive 2-way fanout. In the 4-way fanout into buckets of 2 case this would likely be a smaller saving still.

(I also wrote a benchmark to cause evictions and saw again speedups with a 2-way fanout, but these feel less instructive to me, particularly in the case of block connection.)

In terms of cache sizes, currently these both store ~525,000 32-byte elements with 45% of the cache sized used per-epoch, which equates to \~236,250 elements per epoch. Based on current mempool sizes this seems like more than enough for both caches, which seems to align with my logs seeing \~100% script cache hits during connection.

I did not yet look at tuning the epoch/eviction counter, nor Jeremy's idea of sharing the same table (or making hashes "sticker" by entering them multiple times) as I saw such good hit-rates with the current configuration in block acceptance, but could do so if there was still interest in that...

So overall, whilst there is some performance improvement possible here, I'm not convinces it's particularly worth making changes for.

@willcl-ark you can also look at the memory model and seeing if/how you can make the cache more parallel during block validation. IIRC there is some unnecessary locking which can be eliminated/reduced to something like one acquire/release per thread and a single thread holding a unique lock to prevent writers.
